titleStmt.title: Background color and cultured invertebrates -A review

analytic.title: Background color and cultured invertebrates -A review

biblStruct.note: Received 9 October 2020; Received in revised form 18 January 2021; Accepted 15 February 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: The effect of background color on aquatic invertebrates has been studied for almost two centuries. Many species of aquaculture significance are influenced by this variable. Larval stages appear to benefit from darker backgrounds perhaps because of increased contrast between feed particles. Post-larval invertebrates also gain from background color. Reports indicate that certain species-specific tank colors enhance growth, feed conversion and survival. Reproductive performance, survival success and metamorphosis of larvae may each profit with the selection of suitable background colors. Most commercial tank-based facilities, however, appear limited in their choice of color with green and blue predominating. Use of alternative colors may, however, provide benefit in terms of production performance, animal welfare and economic advantage. Flesh and external coloration too are known to be influenced by the color of rearing environments. These variables are important to consumers as food and ornamental species are often sold with a color-based premium. Animal coloration is likewise important to enhancement programs since release of inappropriately colored animals make them easier prey. This contribution reviews the reported effects of background color on various physiological control and behavioral processes in larval and post-larval marine and freshwater invertebrates with emphasis on crustaceans.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Many organisms can match or blend in with their backgrounds. This camouflaging makes animals less conspicuous, either as predator or prey (Stevens and Merilaita, 2008), and is a common feature of aquatic species. Elasmobranchs (Greenway et al., 2016), teleosts (McLean, 2021), amphibia (Jonnalagadda et al., 1993;Moriya et al., 1996;Holmes et al., 2016), and reptiles (Fontaine et al., 1985;Merchant et al., 2018;Jualaong et al., 2020) each have representatives that can color match their surroundings. Marine and freshwater invertebrates, too, change color to match their backgrounds (Tlusty et al., 2009;Jensen and Egnotovich, 2015;Siegenthaler et al., 2018). They also change color for various behavioral reasons, as exemplified by mate choice and courtship display (e.g., Detto, 2007;Johnsen, 2009a, 2009b). A variety of crustaceans exhibit seasonal changes in pigmentation (Takeshita, 2019), and many amend their color during metamorphosis from larvae to juveniles and during the process of molting (Wenner, 1972;Detto et al., 2008). Certain species express circadian and tidal rhythmicity in pigmentation (Fingerman, 1955); others change color in response to stress (Detto et al., 2008;Takeshita, 2019).

Increasingly, aquatic invertebrates are cultured in tanks and artificial raceways. Tank color has significant effects on the physiology of aquatic animals, and these can negatively or positively impact profitability of producers of food and ornamental species. If outdoors, tank color can influence diurnal water temperatures due to solar absorptivity, convection and conduction (Bergman and Lavine, 2017;Howell et al., 2020) and thence animal growth, feed performance, and among others, levels of stress and welfare. While it is well established that different wavelengths of light affect the behavior and performance of crustaceans (Scott and Mote, 1974;Wang et al., 2003;Baldwin and Johnsen, 2009a;Guo et al., 2011), culturists infrequently have the opportunity to control this variable. On the other hand, tank color may be readily manipulated for indoor and outdoor production. Commercial tanks are most often colored blue, green or black but the rationale for employing these colors is rarely, if ever, specified. As with the effects of different wavelengths, a growing body of evidence indicates that invertebrates react differentially to specific colors and it is conceivable that rearing animals with certain background hues may provide production advantages ( Table 1). The impact of tank color on research outcome is likewise hardly ever contemplated and may, in fact, have significance to the interpretation of findings both within and between laboratories. The following provides a brief overview of the reported impact of background and shelter colors on various performance characteristics of mainly cultured crustaceans, although other species are included for purposes of illustration.

div.head: Homarus americanus
div.p: American lobster

div.head: Pigmentation
div.p: Carotenoids are involved in crustacean pigmentation, photoprotection, and communication, act as antioxidants and provide a source of provitamin A (Britton, 2008). Their origins and relevance to aquaculture, in general, have been considered by Bjerkeng (2008), while Wade et al. (2017), provides a comprehensive overview of carotenoid utilization and function in cultured crustaceans. A thorough account of how crustaceans adapt to their backgrounds, and the molecular endocrinology underlying pigment translocation, is provided by McNamara and Milograna (2015). Adjustments to an individual's coloration may occur gradually, due to changes in pigment cell or chromatophore numbers and metabolic alterations in their constituent pigments, or more rapidly, often within a few minutes, following reorganization of pigment granules. Chromatophores bearing a single pigment granule kind (monochromatic) or cells that lodge two (dichromatic), or more (polychromatic) pigment granule types, frequently cluster, thereby forming chromatosomes. Chromatophores, chromatosomes, and their pigments are responsible for crustaceans adjusting color, actions that are hormonally enabled since crustacean chromatophores are not innervated (Parker, 1930;Fingerman, 1985).

Early research on crustacean color centered attention on environmental adaptation (Kröyer, 1842;Hadley, 1905;Mast, 1909;Pearse, 1911) and the examination of changes in pigment dispersal and migration in pigment cells, or chromatophores (Keeble and Gamble, 1904;Brown, 1934;Brown, 1939a,b). The exposure of many species of crustacean to black or white backgrounds results in darker specimens from the black, and paler animals from white settings (Table 1). There are many examples of this response and it is demonstrated in the fiddler crabs Uca panacea (Kronstadt et al., 2013) and U. pugilator (Carlson, 1935), grass shrimp Palaemonetes vulgaris (Brown, 1934), chameleon Hippolyte varians (Gamble and Keeble, 1900), common Leander (= Palaemon) serratus (Stephenson, 1934), giant freshwater Macrobrachium tenellum (Aréchiga-Palomera et al., 2018), and tiger Penaeus monodon Glencross, 2012, 2014) prawns, among a host of others.

An early example of changes in the distribution of pigment in chromatophores of crabs held on backgrounds other than white and black used redhair, Portunus ordwayi, and delicate P. anceps, swimming crabs. Holding on red and black backgrounds caused an aggregation of white pigment, but dispersal of black and yellow pigments in both species, resulting in darker-colored specimens (Abramowitz, 1935). While this is a common feature of many species, it is notable that some, such as pelagic phase American lobster Homarus americanus, Crangon crangon, and Palaemon sp., have been observed as unresponsive to background color, even after extended periods of exposure (Agassiz, 1892; but see Table 1). Similar null reactions have been reported for southern rock lobster Jasus edwardsii, even following 12-month holding on various colored backgrounds (Stuart et al., 1996). From the literature it appears that the ability to influence morphological color by holding crustaceans in colored tanks is variable and perhaps species dependent. Nonetheless, for some invertebrates, exposure to a specific color can result in body color change and this negates or reduces any need for expensive pigment-containing feeds. Body color is important not only to consumers, who use it as a quality trait during purchasing (Shahidi and Brown, 1998;Erickson et al., 2007), but also to crustacean stock enhancement programs for reasons of camouflage (Mynott et al., 2018).

div.head: Quality attributes
div.p: Crustacean color can vary broadly dependent on rearing environments and these variations can potentially influence consumer acceptability and pricing for edible and ornamental species , Wade et al., 2015aCalvo et al., 2016;Li et al., 2020). Hence, it is important to optimize captive rearing conditions to ensure preservation or improve color demanded by clients. For example, species, such as rock or spiny lobsters, are often graded by color (Chandrapavan et al., 2009) with red individuals being more valuable, especially in Far Eastern markets, than paler animals (Arcenal, 2004). While the western rock lobster, Panulirus cygnus, responds to background, becoming paler when held in white tanks, and pinkish-coral on darker backgrounds, they nevertheless fail to attain the darker color of their inshore wild conspecifics, known as "reds". This makes them less desirable and hence less valuable (Melville-Smith et al., 2003). Cultured spiny lobsters from fattening operations also are cheaper than those from the fishery due to their inferior taste and color (Arcenal, 2004). Accordingly, to maintain color during fattening, use of pigment-containing diets has been proposed (Barclay et al., 2006;Soffa et al., 2019).

In contrast to spiny or rock lobsters, tiger prawns Penaeus monodon, and Pacific white leg shrimp Litopenaeus vannamei, reared using a black or white background present as dark blue-black, and pale brown-grey colors, respectively (Parisenti et al., 2011a; Table 1). Cooking changes their color to a reddish-orange hue, with those from black tanks presenting a much deeper, market-favored, reddish-orange color (Tume et al., 2009;Limsuwan et al., 2009;Parisenti et al., 2011a;. This effect was noticed well within 30 days of shrimp being placed into black tanks and has been reported to impact cooked color even within 24 h in L. vannamei (Kritch et al., 2020). Analyses of extracted carotenoids from P. monodon determined that free astaxanthin levels were reduced, while esterified astaxanthin was higher in prawns held in white tanks (Tume et al., 2009); providing a possible biochemical explanation for variations in cooked color. There is a potential problem, however. As pointed out by Parisenti et al. (2011b), consumers prefer light colored raw shrimp that are bright orange-red when cooked; but lighter shrimp are paler when cooked. To attain optimal consumer preference, therefore, it may be necessary to use a combination of dietary pigment and tank color (see Wade et al., 2015a,b) either way, the use of appropriate tank colors will result in savings by reducing pigment feed costs.

While edible shrimp are generally priced according to size, one of the most important quality criteria for both freshwater and marine ornamental shrimp is color (Laohavisuti and Ruangdej, 2014;Díaz-Jiménez et al., 2018). This is beautifully illustrated by the freshwater red cherry shrimp Neocaridina (= hetropoda) davidi. This species' lowest grade is the ordinary red cherry shrimp, which is semi-transparent and covered by red dots. The Sakura grade has a more intense red color on the carapace, with high-grade Sakura expressing deeper red along the carapace and abdomen. These ratings are followed by red fire, painted red fire, and bloody Mary grades, each of which exhibit deeper red pigmentation (Anon, 2020). The price differential can be US$1.00 for ordinary red cherry through to US$8.50 (and a lot higher) for tank-bred bloody Mary varieties (Price, 2019). Many commercial breeders of this ornamental shrimp employ astaxanthin and other carotenoids in feeds to enhance red coloration, increasing the value of cultured animals over those taken from the wild. For example, marigold astaxanthin-containing feed and different backgrounds were examined by Laohavisuti and Ruangdej (2014), to verify whether this approach augmented Neocaridina heteropoda color. Over an eight-week trial, they found that total carotenoids in shrimp reared on red and black backgrounds were greater and pigmentation more intense than those measured in shrimp cultured in white settings. Also using black, red, and white backgrounds and Neocaridina davidi, Tomas et al. (2020), reported that animals held on black for 90 days expressed increased astaxanthin content and carapace color. Comparable results have been recorded for other ornamental species (Table 1) and it is clear that when red is the preferred body color, the rearing environment should be black/red, with or without pigmented feeds. This strategy represents an inexpensive method to add value to final products and, since more vibrant red shrimp can be achieved than found in the wild with this combination, it may work towards preserving natural stocks.

div.head: Stock enhancement
div.p: Stock enhancement has been employed with a variety of crustaceans, on a global basis, with varying degrees of success, for decades. These programs have been initiated to replenish extinct, naturally depleted, and overfished populations, and to increase the size of fished individuals. Indeed, culture-based restocking efforts with European and American lobsters have been ongoing since the 19 th Century (Moquin-Tandon and Soubeiran, 1865; Dannevig, 1885;Rathbun, 1886;Appelløf, 1909), although interest in enhancing brachyuran fisheries has been more recent (Fushimi, 1983;Obata et al., 2006;Zohar et al., 2008;Hamasaki et al., 2011). The importance of background color matching, or morphological conditioning, to aquaculture stock enrichment programs has been considered by several authors. For example, Mynott et al. (2018), suggested that if pelagic phase larvae of European lobsters were to be released, they would benefit from being either translucent or lightly colored to assist evasion of predators. In contrast, if later stage, settled animals, are to be used, these would be advantaged by being darker in color. There are, however, contradictions in the literature, with Agassiz (1892) reporting lack of success in modifying the color of pelagic phase lobsters, while others were able to do so (Siegenthaler et al., 2018; Table 1). Mynott et al. (2018) suggested that settlement might even act as a trigger for deepening coloration in Homarus spp. when settlement backgrounds are dark -on light colored backgrounds, juveniles expressed small changes in luminance to better match their surroundings. If lobster, or other crustacean enhancement programs are to employ the benthic phase at release, therefore, their holding in black tanks may be advantageous as an anti-predator defense, provided their ultimate placement were to be on a dark substrate. However, Davis et al. (2005) reported that conditioning of juvenile blue crabs, Callinectes sapidus, to a darker color before release into the wild was without apparent benefit. Similar observations have been made for European lobster H. gammarus regarding environment enrichment for juveniles prior to simulated release (Aspaas et al., 2016). Pigmentation of enhancement animals may be of less importance if they are released in habitats that express high turbidity/low visibility, or when predators hunt by chemical cues rather than with vision. Although hatchery systems and culture technologies for cold-water clawed lobsters have been designed and evaluated (Drengstig and Bergheim, 2013;Jeffs et al., 2020), and post-larval diets developed (Hinchcliffe et al., 2020), their slow-growth, territoriality, aggressiveness, and cannibalistic nature have stymied development of an industry (Jeffs et al., 2020). The ability to manipulate body color through background manipulations might, however, provide stimulus to industry development, since darker colored lobsters command higher market prices, which may offset their cost of production.

div.head: Cover preference
div.p: In-tank and pond shelters can act to provide protection from predation, aggression, and cannibalism while also decreasing stress and the chances of intrusion and antagonistic behaviors in conspecifics (Mirera and Moksnes, 2013;Kawamura et al., 2017). However, they have also been reported to increase aggressive competition for occupation and cannibalism (Nakata and Goshima, 2003). Shelter preference in adult purple mud crabs S. tranquebarica, was examined by Kawamura et al. (2020a), using paired PVC tubes painted in different colors. They reported a marked preference for blue over any other color assessed (Table 1) and hypothesized that touch stimuli of the shelter lowered aggression, stress, and cannibalism, with existing occupants tolerating intruders and allowing cohabitation. This suggestion appears to be supported by the observations of Mirera and Moksnes (2013) who recorded reduced aggressiveness in S. serrata in the presence of shelters. Other species, such as the hermit crab Calcinus tubularis, appear to select shelters based on shell coloration: dark crabs choosing darker shells (Pessani and Tirelli, 2006). Shelter texture and color has been observed to influence the burrowing behavior of Macrobrachium nobilii, with avoidance of transparent shelters and preference of young and adults for darker-colored shelters (Mariappan and Balasundaram, 2003). M. malcolmsonii and M. nobilii both preferred black versus brown shelters (Balasundaram et al., 2004), whereas dos , reported that M. rosenbergii equally preferred orange and red (Table 1). In crayfish Procambarus spp., Blank and Figler (1996) observed a preference for black rough-textured shelters over that of white or black smoothtextured retreats. H. americanus also avoided transparent shelters, preferring opaque sanctuaries (Cobb, 1971). Thus, depending on species, shelters of various colors function to suppress aggressiveness, decrease excavation in ponds, and provide protected mating compartments. Clearly, color preference differences exist between species and ages for shelters and these may even differ from background choices. Shape, size, shelter texture, and construction materials employed, likely also play a role in the selection process.

div.head: Live feeds
div.p: Traditionally, marine fish and invertebrate hatcheries use a variety of live feeds to aid the transition of larvae to metamorphosed juveniles (Støttrup and McEvoy, 2003). These operations often require feeds of various sizes since, throughout crustacean and fish developmental phases, feeding and food handling and capture capabilities increase. Prey capture depends also on the interaction of background color with light to provide contrast (Ma et al., 2015), which improves the ability of the predator to distinguish prey due to variation in luminance enhancing visual acuity in a specific visual field (Dehmelt et al., 2020). Historically, rotifers (Brachionus spp.; Wallace and Uyhelji, 2016) and (un)enriched Artemia nauplii, metanauplii, juveniles and adults (Browne et al., 2018) have been employed during the culture of larvae. Over the last few decades, however, it has been recognized that copepods offer superior nutritional qualities to either of the aforementioned live feeds and, moreover, their nauplii and adult forms greatly widen the size distribution of the live feed pantry (Lee et al., 2005;Drillet et al., 2006). Too, they offer up the means to culture a broader variety of invertebrates, and fish species whose larvae may have smaller prey-width-to-mouth-width ratios.

Irrespective of what live food is used, optimized culture is especially important in the hatchery environment where mass quantities of two or more live feeds may be required to accommodate various larviculture protocols, several times per year. There are potentially three issues that should be considered with respect to tank color. First, the effect of tank color on rotifer population growth has been examined using Brachionus rotundiformis, both under 24 h and 12h light-12h dark photoperiods (Maliclic et al., 2019). These studies determined that black tanks represented the optimal color for production (Table 1), providing highest densities and specific growth rates under 24 h illumination. It was suggested by the authors that the black rearing unit diminished light intensity and served to reduce rotifer aggregations and competition for resources (food, space, and oxygen) by encouraging a more even distribution in the water column. Second, because highly pigmented live feeds of specific color, or transparent species that color up due to the presence of parasites or gut content, tend to be more heavily preyed upon by visual feeders (e.g., Bakker et al., 1997;Tsuda et al., 2003;Zhang et al., 2015), manipulation of prey color through background imprinting may offer potential to beneficially accent feeds in the water column. Lastly, tank color may simplify feed harvesting. For example, the separation of Artemia nauplii, and other phototactic feed organisms, from their egg/cyst casings, detritus, and unhatched eggs, is eased using illumination over black-walled tanks and harvesting, using plankton netting, facilitated due to increased contrast (Persoone and Sorgeloos, 1972).

Studies that center attention on live feed organisms and tank color remain desperately scarce. Because of this they offer considerable opportunities for research. For example, there are no evaluations of the effect of background color on feeding success and grazing rates of live prey. Information on the ability to manipulate the eventual coloration of live feeds is also lacking, even though many fish and invertebrate larvae show a food color preference (Dendrinos et al., 1984;Ma et al., 2015;Zhang et al., 2015). As well, there is no awareness of the potential effect that tank color may have on rates of live feed metamorphosis.

div.head: Larval crustaceans
div.p: The metamorphosis of a marine crustacean was first described by Thompson (1828), but it was not until the late 1950s that full accounts of the development of captively cultivated decapods was documented (Snodgrass, 1956;Broad, 1957;Costlow and Bookhout, 1960). These, and subsequent studies, unveiled the complexities of larval crustacean settlement, revealing its dependence on multiple sensory inputs that integrate visual, photobehavioral, chemical, tactile, vibrational, and or other cues (Epifanio and Cohen, 2016;Anger et al., 2020). However, the impact of substrate and or tank color on larval crustacean development and survival has been examined only occasionally. Still, more rapid, and synchronous moulting and better water column distribution was observed for larval mangrove crab Scylla serrata, reared in black tanks (Rabbani and Zeng, 2005). And, although tank color did not influence their survival, a higher rate of cannibalism was apparently observed in black tanks (Table 1). It was suggested that the performance of larvae in black tanks correlated with feeding success; the black walls contrasting feed particles (Brachionus and Artemia nauplii). Blue swimming crab Portunus pelagicus, larvae exhibited higher survival, more rapid development and better SGR in black and red tanks when compared with orange, yellow and white (Azra et al., 2012); with only those in the black and red tanks achieving the megalopa stage. In marked contrast, larvae of the gazami crab, P. trituberculatus, expressed a significant preference from zoea I to megalopa for white backgrounds. However, best survival rates and fastest developmental times were recorded in red and yellow containers (Shi et al., 2019). Animals held in red and white containers expressed lower oxygen consumption rates, perhaps indicating decreased levels of stress.

Several studies have examined the effect of background color on the giant freshwater or river prawns (Macrobrachium sp.; Table 1). Thus, Yasharian et al. (2005) found no effect for color on the size of post-larvae (PL) but survival was higher in green and red tanks when compared against white and blue backgrounds. The Aquacop group (1977) likewise reported a preference for dark green tanks but failed to report colors of other tanks examined. Best survival was obtained for Amazon river prawn M. amazonicum larvae maintained in black tanks, with poorest results being recorded from red, yellow, and white containers (Maciel and Valenti, 2014). Highest feeding rate was also recorded for prawn larvae held in black tanks (Lin and Omori, 1993), while Rodrigues et al. (1998) found that while tank color did not impact larval feeding or capture rates, PL were heavier and larger and recovery rates higher from black tanks compared to white. In contrast, developmental rates and survival were observed as superior in violet tanks when compared against five other colors (Shelke et al., 2010; Table 1), and it is possible that a relationship between speed of metamorphosis and survival exists. A caveat about the latter study, however, was that no black tanks were included in the trial. Accordingly, for Macrobrachium sp. dark (black, dark green and violet) tanks should be further evaluated before final selection of color(s) to be employed within hatcheries. It would appear, however, with few reported exceptions, that darker colors, and especially red and black, represent favored hues for Macrobrachium sp. The larvae of cultured invertebrates, with few exceptions, generally express better overall performance in dark colored tanks, with an apparent preference for black backgrounds. These observed benefits have been attributed to improved feed contrast, resulting in greater food capture success, consequent augmented growth, hastened metamorphosis and survival (Table 1).

div.head: Juvenile and adult responses
div.p: Tank and background color influence survival, growth, and performance of juvenile and adult stages of several invertebrate species of aquaculture significance. For example, in M. rosenbergii, more weight is gained, and higher survival achieved, when they are reared in black tanks (Juarez et al., 1987). Better growth has also been reported for juvenile peppermint shrimp Lysmata wurdemanni, maintained in black tanks (Díaz-Jiménez et al., 2018), and weight gain and SGR for the red cherry shrimp N. heteropoda increased as background color darkened (Laohavisuti and Ruangdej, 2014). In the swimming crab, Portunus trituberculatus, growth was elevated in blue and red colored tanks when compared against black, green, white and yellow (Wang et al., 2019). On the other hand, L. vannamei show a preference for red and yellow walled tanks with like-colored substrates (Table 1); both feeding and specific growth rates were, however, highest in red tanks (Luchiari et al., 2012).

Mate choice may be color dependent -it certainly plays a role in species recognition, decapod signaling, competition, and sexual selection Johnsen, 2009a, 2009b;Taro, 2018). However, no research has explicitly been undertaken to examine the influence of background color on mate choice and reproductive performance with invertebrates. Nonetheless, Chiou et al. (2011), demonstrated that depriving the male smasher stomatopod Haptosquilla trispinosa, of bright blue polarized light signals reduced their overall chance of female acceptance, underlining the importance of male color in guiding female behavior when interacting with potential partners. Coloration is also important in mate choice for anomuran and brachyuran crabs (Caro, 2018) but is apparently without import on Allegheny crayfish Faxonius obscurus (Hartzell, 2020). When mate availability is high, female decapod crustaceans tend to be promiscuous and may carry broods with multiple paternity (McLeay and Dennenmoser, 2020), such that manipulation of mate color may be less valuable in a hatchery setting. It is noteworthy that orange mud crabs Scylla olivacea, had a high induced mating success in black tanks (Asmat-Ullah et al., 2021), and, although other colors were not evaluated, it is possible that darker tanks represent the choice for soft-shelled portunids and other species.

Perhaps predictably, berried freshwater prawns released greater numbers of larvae when held in dark, compared to transparent tanks (Abbas et al., 2018). Unfortunately, the latter study did not evaluate a broader variety of colors such that whether this variable has an influence on egg release remains equivocal. Although there is only scant evidence, for some cultured invertebrates specific background colors may induce enhanced nuptial coloration, accelerate mate choice and mating, and increase/synchronize egg release. Such possibilities are certainly deserved of future examination for improving production efficiency. It is apparent that ontogenetic shifts, between juvenile and adult, and gender-based preferences for color may occur in some species, especially as this relates to shelter color (dos da Costa et al., 2020). Background colors may reduce stress and thereby provide benefit by optimizing growth, health, and welfare. However, to date, no study has explicitly examined the impact of tank color on stress or disease status in cultured invertebrateseven though stress might be inferred from negative growth effects of some colors (Table 1). Stress events have been assessed using various markers. including changes in glucose, antioxidant capacity, total hemocyte counts and phagocytic capacity, disturbance in heat shock proteins and innate immunity, and, among others, measurement of changes in gene expression profiles (Garrido et al., 2017;Mustafa et al., 2019;Chen and He, 2019;Han et al., 2020). As has been undertaken with teleosts (McLean, 2021), application of any or all these methods would provide rapid evaluation of the existence of color-related stress in invertebrates and provide evidence to support selection of most favorable background color. Another area worthy of consideration would be the evaluation of stress and welfare effects, of holding tank color during transportation, and within the live animal retail and restaurant sectors.

div.head: Corals, urchins, sea cucumbers and mollusks
div.p: Other cultivated invertebrates that respond to background color include members of the Cnidaria, Echinodermata and Mollusca. Increasing pressure on and losses of coral reef systems due to a wide variety of factors, varying from microplastic pollution to destructive fishing practices, poor governance and climate change (Pandolfi et al., 2003;Hughes et al., 2018;Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2017;Cheal et al., 2017;Morrison et al., 2020), has intensified efforts to develop methods for their aquaculture. Corals are now cultivated for reef restoration, public exhibition, reef, or rock garden aquarists, for ornament and a growing biomedical sector (Demers et al., 2002;Macha and Ben-Nissan, 2018;Barton et al., 2017). A critical component of coral culture is the settlement of planula larvae on suitable substrates. Without appropriate settlement cues planula larvae may retain their larval state and die (Barton et al., 2017). Although there are several known chemical and physical cues that induce planula to settle and metamorphose, some species preferentially alight on materials of specific color. Thus, irrespective of material employed (plastic, acrylic), Mason et al. (2011), observed that larvae from the brooding-hermaphroditic mustard hill coral (Porites asteroids), preferentially settled and metamorphosed on red substrates when presented with a variety of color options (blue, green, orange, pink, purple, and white). Larvae from the spawning elkhorn coral (Acropora palmata) also illustrated this preference. The authors suggested that sensitivity to red substrates may provide a mechanism for positioning larvae in habitats that improve juvenile and adult survival. This color cuing may enhance the probability for the gregarious settlement of larvae of eventually sessile organismsand thereby increase their reproductive potential. Interestingly, the spectral signature of adults -their natural red fluorescence -may also color cue larval settlement, thereby enhancing population grouping (Matsumura and Qian, 2014). In a coral hatchery environment, therefore, red colored tanks for the above-named species at least, would be expected to increase larval settlement, metamorphosis, and survival. Studies in this area are nonetheless sparse and it is possible that different color substrates might be favored by other species. It is notable that Matsumura and Qian (2014), reported that cyprid larvae of the sessile striped barnacle (Amphibalanus amphitrite), also favored settlement on red surfaces over blue, green, and yellow (P < 0.001). Similar observations were made for barnacles by Siddik and Satheesh (2021).

Aquacultured echinoderms include sea urchins and a variety of sea cucumber species. They are used for food (Lawrence, 2007), in biomedical applications (Macha and Ben-Nissan, 2018) and urchins have been employed extensively as models in developmental biology (Foltz and Hamdoun, 2019). A critical stage in the production of sea cucumbers is their metamorphosis from the non-feeding doliolaria larval form to the settled pentacula phase. Settlement in the hatchery is encouraged by coating polythene sheets or plates with chemical cues, Spirulina, diatoms, and/or seaweed extracts. In addition, the effect of substrate color (black, blue, green, red, yellow) on attachment of Japanese spiky sea cucumber (Apostichopus japonicus) doliolaria revealed a highly significant preference for red (Qiao et al., 2012). Juveniles, on the other hand, were more attracted to green, red and blue substrates when compared to black, yellow and white (Dong et al., 2010), although Lin et al. (2012), reported black as the preferred color compared against others examined (red, blue, green, white and transparent) for adult A. japonicus. Conversely, Zacharías-Soto et al. (2013) reported no preference shown by the four-sided sea cucumber Isostichopus badionotus, for blue, green, white or yellow plastic plates, with larvae settling only on the tank bottom in areas of reduced light. These contradictory findings suggest that settlement preferences among echinoderms are speciesspecific. However, the meager number of trials prevent any meaningful conclusions in an area deserved of greater investigation.

The Mollusca are the second largest invertebrate phylum and incorporate the cephalopods (octopi, cuttlefishes and squids), gastropods such as abalone, and bivalves exemplified by mussels, clams, and oysters. They have been an important source of hominin food for at least 160,000 years (Jerardino, 2016) and may represent the Paleolithic's protoaquaculture phylum (McLean and Al-Rashdi, 2015). However, relatively few studies have examined the relationship of the phylum with background color. Those that have been undertaken mostly evaluate the effect of color on bivalve spat collection both in the wild and hatchery settings. Although spat collection from the wild represents the preeminent method of harvesting, hatchery-based spat production is growing in importance and will ultimately become more routinely used to stabilize supplies, for selective breeding programs, ploidy manipulations and production of pathogen-free stocks (Smaal et al., 2019).

Black and red predominated as colors for the settlement of South Sea pearl oyster Pinctada maxima spat, when compared against yellow and white (Wang et al., 2017). For the Mazatlan pearl oyster P. mazatlanica, red and green bag interiors were favored over black (Saucedo et al., 2005), while greatest settlement of Akoya pearl oyster P. martensii spat was observed on red and blue rather than green and yellow (P < 0.05) sheets (Su et al., 2007). Clearly, for Pinctada spp. red represents a preferred color substrate for spat settlement. This selection likely relates to red and darker colors being less reflective, providing greater cryptic advantage -a supposition supported by the preference of invertebrates for shaded over bright surroundings (Miller and Etter, 2008;Siddik and Satheesh, 2021). No preference for red and green colored collectors were expressed by either the European winged oyster Pteria hirundo (Salvador et al., 2011) or Korean mussels Mytilus coruscus (Li et al., 2017), however.

Due to rising demand and value, a growing marketplace, and stagnation or declines in some fisheries, commercial capture of Coleoidea (octopi, cuttlefish and squid) has increased over the last 40 years (Sauer et al., 2019;FAO, 2020). Even so, interest in the potential of cephalopods as species for culture has increased due to regional fishery declines and the fact that they express rapid growth, good feed conversion, high fecundity and easily adapt to captive conditions. However, difficulty has been encountered in mass production, especially of paralarvae (Iglesias et al., 2007), which has mainly restricted culture to juvenile fattening operations. Nevertheless, studies have determined that cuttlefish, Sepia officinalis, hatchlings and juveniles perform best, in terms of growth, when held in black tanks (Sykes et al., 2011). On the other hand, paralarvae of O. vulgaris demonstrated no differences in ingestion rates of Artemia when held on either white or blue backgrounds (Márquez et al., 2007). But, two species of adult octopi (Octopus vulgaris and O. aegina), were selective for black, red and orange when offered a choice of seven background colors (Okamoto et al., 2001). Based on the prominence of translucent prey organisms black and dark grey tanks have been recommended for the feeding of hatchling squid since these colors reflect less incident light (Lee et al., 1998). While it appears that juvenile and adult cephalopods show a marked preference for darker backgrounds, further studies are nonetheless required to establish a norm for display, research and production purposes. The effects of tank color on behavior, stress and health-related issues are especially important from a research perspective due to cephalopods being afforded specific guidelines for use under EU, UK and other directives (Fiorito et al., 2014).

div.head: Outlook
div.p: Invertebrate pigmentation may be influenced by a variety of extrinsic and intrinsic factors (Smith, 1930;Brown and Sandeen, 1948;Detto et al., 2008;Stevens et al., 2013) and background clearly represents a discrete variable that affects a variety of production-related physiological control processes in many species (Table 1). However, as previously pointed out (McLean, 2021), when considering color it is not enough to simply state that a tank was "red". There are over 440 named red colors; just as there are over 270 blues, that vary in hue, chroma/ saturation and lightness/brightness, so to state that a tank was "red in color" is of limited value. Thus, it is difficult to draw meaningful judgments, and hence conclusions, between tank color studies. If suitable background colors are to be chosen for specific tasks (live food production, larval rearing, enhancement, stress mitigation, etc.), it is essential that future trials report tank or background coloration using a coherent classification system such as those presented by Hunter, CIE2000/DE2000, and the CIELab color space methods. Likewise, similar approaches should be used when reporting changes in animal body or flesh color, whether by assessment of images or raw material. Examples of the application of such methods are presented in a variety of papers (e.g., Tlusty and Hyland, 2005;Calvo et al., 2016;Díaz-Jiménez et al., 2018). Color measurements should be made at the commencement of each study since color hue, chroma/saturation and lightness/brightness may be impacted by natural light, weathering, etc. Indeed, from a research perspective tank color should always be reported using reliable methods of quantification to enable appropriate repetition of research and to facilitate meaningful comparisons between results.

When it comes to vision, invertebrates exhibit a wide range of morphological and developmental complexity (Warrant, 2019). For example, in the Mollusca, bivalves exhibit pallial eyes, gastropods have cephalic eyes, and cephalopods camerular types. Others, as illustrated by echinoderms, have more rudimentary capabilities with some expressing compound eyes made up of ommatidia and others, like that of many holothurians, exhibiting ocelli, and a few, such as sea urchins, expressing photoreceptor cells (Yoshida et al., 1984;Garm and Nilsson, 2014;Ullrich-Lüter al., 2011). The latter structures, rather than providing vision, offer what has been termed extraocular photoreceptive abilities. The wide variety, structure, optics, visual pigments, and function of larval crustacean eyes has been reviewed by Cronin et al. (2017). The many species able to detect a broader range of color than humans are exemplified by the stomatopods (Thoen et al, 2014;Marshall, 2017). Many can distinguish polarized light (Shashar et al., 2004;Smithers, 2019), others, such as the cephalopods, are monochromats -unable to discern color (Hanke and Kelber, 2020). While studies on color generally have the starting point of establishing that test animals have color vision, animals do not have to possess color vision to respond differentially to color. This is hinted at with the fact that while many species apparently respond to color, they are known to be monochromatic or, in the case of many molluscan, echinoderm or cnidarian larvae, only express photoreceptive capability. Positive response to color in such cases must, therefore, relate more to how light spectra matches the spectral sensitivity of photoreceptor pigmentsthe intensity of a color's brightness rather than the color itself. Thus, studies with color should be designed to enable comparison of an animal's responses to differences in intensity of spectral composition (Ells et al., 2016). Accordingly, the inclusion of black, white and grey backgrounds would benefit interpretations.

Studies on the impact of color on stress, immune function, gene expression, and reproduction, in general, are extremely rare for aquacultured species in general, but especially for invertebrates. Evidently, background color has measurable influence on growth, product quality, size uniformity, survival, larval metamorphosis, reproduction, stress, and animal welfare, among others (Table 1). Each of these variables represent potential economic impact to production and performance characteristics of animals under cultivation. Color plasticity in many species would indicate that hatchery and on-growing conventions could be easily modified to include changes in the colors of tank and substrates to optimize production performance. While it is likely that color alone represents only a single cue of many it nonetheless offers positive advantages and although it may be difficult to envisage production or research units full of red, violet, or indeed, yellow tanks, this may represent a tangible future.
